latestVersion.restrictions: These data are subject to copyright and are licensed for current members of the MIT Community. You may make a copy of this data for your own use. You may not make copies, full or partial, for distribution, in any manner.
latestVersion.termsOfAccess: MIT affiliates should access this dataset by logging into Dataverse and selecting Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Data are restricted to members of the MIT community and for the purposes of research, education, and scholarship.

fields.value: International Terrorism: Attributes of Terrorist Events (ITERATE), 1968-2015

dsDescriptionValue.value: The ITERATE project is an attempt to quantify data on the characteristics of transnational terrorist groups, their activities which have international impact, and the environment in which they operate. ITERATE 3 and 4 update the coverage of terrorist incidents first reported in ITERATE 1 and 2, which can be obtained from the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research. The dataset consists of four parts. Nearly all incidents appear in the COMMON file, which the FATE, HOSTAGE and SKYJACK files supplement. Some non-terrorist domestic skyjackings appear in the SKYJACK file and not in the COMMON file. In cases in which we know what happened to the terrorists, we record their destiny in the FATE file. Variables specific to hostage-taking incidents, inc luding aerial, land, and sea hijackings, barricade-and-hostage situations, and kidnappings are provided in the HOSTAGE file.

fields.value: MIT affiliates should access this dataset by logging into Dataverse and selecting Massachusetts Institute of Technology.Before uploading to the repository, files that were in a proprietary format (.xls, .doc) were converted to open formats and uploaded in addition to the original files supplied by the publisher.;

value: Sources include: global news media; chronologies provided by foreign embassies to the US and UN Missions; chronologies provided by CIA, National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC), the Department of State, Federal Aviation Administration, FBI, and other federal law enforcement agencies; memoirs by hostages and other victims; published research reports from think tanks, FFRDCs, and other government contractors whose materials were subsequently released
